title: Ireland faces time zone border after Brexit European Parliament vote to scrap saving daylight time
text:
Ireland faces the possibility of a baffling 'time zone border' after Brexit.

The European Parliament voted to scrap daylight saving time in March with the changes due to come into force in autumn 2021.

If member states give it the go ahead, EU countries will no longer put their clocks back in autumn and forward in spring.

But this would mean a time zone difference between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, with the province still adhering to Greenwich Mean Time and British Summer Time.

The 'time zone border' will only become a reality if 55 per cent of EU member states back the legislation.

The island of Ireland faces a 'time zone border' with the EU planning to scrap daylight saving time and the UK firmly against making the change

Those countries can then choose whether they want a 'permanent summer' or 'permanent winter' and which time zone they wish to adopt.

Currently Dublin follows the same time zone as London and Belfast.

The UK Government is staunchly against scrapping daylight saving time, which was introduced through the Summer Time Act of 1916.

The clocks went back on Sunday October 27, giving the UK an extra hour in bed as it switched back to GMT.

British Summer Time officially came to an end with the clocks 'falling backwards' and colder winter weather on the way.

The Summer Time Act was brought in to give farmers an extra hour of daylight to work in a bid to increase output.

Originally, this was to contribute towards the war effort, since there was more light in the evenings.

It had been discussed for a number of years beforehand by the Government but many people opposed it the first time around.
description: The EU's plans to scrap daylight saving time could mean the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland following different time zones.
